name: Spanakopita
description: Recipe video above. Spanakopita - the iconic traditional Greek Spinach Pie with layers upon layers of golden buttery flaky filo pastry. For the best Spanakopita of your life, use raw rather than cooked spinach, and layer the phyllo pastry with finely shredded Greek cheese so it sticks together rather than flying everywhere when you cut it!This pie is a perfect thickness with a good ratio of Spinach Feta filling to pastry. It will serve 4 to 5 people as a main dish.
recipeIngredient: 60g / 2/3 cup  Greek Kefalotyri cheese (, finely grated (sub parmesan, Note 3))
1/2 tsp white sesame seeds ((or more black))
1/2 tsp black sesame seeds ((or more white))

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 220°C/430°F (200°C fan). Line a tray with baking paper / parchment paper.
recipeInstructions.name: Preheat oven to 220°C/430°F (200°C fan). Line a tray with baking paper / parchment paper.

itemListElement.text: Sweat spinach: Place spinach in a large colander or bowl. Sprinkle with salt, toss through. Leave for 10 minutes to sweat.
itemListElement.name: Sweat spinach: Place spinach in a large colander or bowl. Sprinkle with salt, toss through. Leave for 10 minutes to sweat.

itemListElement.text: Wring out water: Place a handful of spinach in a tea towel, then wring out tightly to remove excess water.
itemListElement.name: Wring out water: Place a handful of spinach in a tea towel, then wring out tightly to remove excess water.

itemListElement.text: Filling: Place spinach in a bowl with remaining Filling ingredients. Mix well to combine.
itemListElement.name: Filling: Place spinach in a bowl with remaining Filling ingredients. Mix well to combine.

itemListElement.text: Trim filo: Cut 16 sheets of filo pastry into 32 x 25cm / 13 x 10" (pictured) or 26cm / 10.5" square.
itemListElement.name: Trim filo: Cut 16 sheets of filo pastry into 32 x 25cm / 13 x 10" (pictured) or 26cm / 10.5" square.

itemListElement.text: 8 base layers: Layer 8 sheets of filo pastry on the tray, brushing each layer with melted butter.
itemListElement.name: 8 base layers: Layer 8 sheets of filo pastry on the tray, brushing each layer with melted butter.

itemListElement.text: Filling: Spread filling on filo pastry. Smooth surface and leave a 2.5cm / 1" border.
itemListElement.name: Filling: Spread filling on filo pastry. Smooth surface and leave a 2.5cm / 1" border.

itemListElement.text: 8 Filo topping layers (Note 4): Cover spinach with a sheet of filo pastry. Brush with butter, sprinkle with Kefalotyri. Repeat for Sheets #2 to #5. Then cover with filo sheets #6 to #8, brushing with butter in between, but do NOT sprinkle with cheese (neater finish).
itemListElement.name: 8 Filo topping layers (Note 4): Cover spinach with a sheet of filo pastry. Brush with butter, sprinkle with Kefalotyri. Repeat for Sheets #2 to #5. Then cover with filo sheets #6 to #8, brushing with butter in between, but do NOT sprinkle with cheese (neater finish).

itemListElement.text: Seal: Press edges down to seal. Crimp and trim if desired (see process steps in post or video) or just leave the edges flat on the tray.
itemListElement.name: Seal: Press edges down to seal. Crimp and trim if desired (see process steps in post or video) or just leave the edges flat on the tray.

itemListElement.text: Sesame seeds: Brush the top with butter, sprinkle with sesame seeds.
itemListElement.name: Sesame seeds: Brush the top with butter, sprinkle with sesame seeds.

itemListElement.text: Bake: Bake 25 minutes, or until golden brown on the surface.
itemListElement.name: Bake: Bake 25 minutes, or until golden brown on the surface.

itemListElement.text: Serve! Serve immediately! It is at its absolute prime fresh out of the oven, though still good as long as its hot (~15 min or so). The base does lose crispiness as it cools.
itemListElement.name: Serve! Serve immediately! It is at its absolute prime fresh out of the oven, though still good as long as its hot (~15 min or so). The base does lose crispiness as it cools.

review.reviewBody:
I’ve also made this using pre-washed baby spinach. Honestly? It’s much easier.
Leftovers freeze well. . Just defrost and reheat in the oven, just ensure any exposed filling is protected.

Unbelievable! So filling ( I may have had 50/75 gms more spinach). Everyone eating seconds, and for my GF relative, worked better with GF puff than rice flour wraps. Flavour was incredible- and combined it with the Greek Lamb salad …..magnificent!

What do you make when your generous neighbour gives you a bag of homegrown spinach? Spanakopita of course! First time making it today. Absolutely delicious. I was surprised how easy it was & I even had a go at crimping the edge. Another winner thanks to you Nagi xx
I cooked this at 220C and before 25 mins was even close it started to burn.  Next time I’ll try 180C and check every 5 mins.   Flavor was great though.
This is an amazing recipe. Turned out better than I expected. I used my own home grown silver beet instead of spinach. Crowd favourite. x
I really enjoyed this. I made the pastry from scratch which was a surprisingly simple, but very time consuming and satisfying prelude to this delicious dish. The uncooked spinach is a game changer!

Can confirm you CAN freeze an uncooked spanakopita and cook with a perfectly crispy bottom. Here’s what I did:
* Make the spinach and cheese filling, then cover and leave in the fridge at least overnight. (I left mine 48 hours.) Excess water will rise to the top and can be gently poured off. Make pie as directed and wrap well for freezing.
* Do the breadcrumb trick mentioned earlier - line the tray you bake on with breadcrumbs to soak up excess moisture.  (I don’t think I had any excess moisture anyway.)
* If cooking from fully frozen, cook at 150C for 30 mins before increasing the temperature to 200C for 25 mins.
It was perfect and delicious!
SUCH a delicious filling & love the sprinkling of cheese between the filo layers! Thank you Nagi!!
It's from her Borek recipe, 1 egg, 2 tbsp Greek yogurt and 2 tbsp melted butter.  Awesome
So easy to make & so delicious! Used big bag of baby spinach, found it really easy to work with, wasn't overly wet and it turned out beautiful!

Hi Nagi
Just letting you know I just cooked this for my church. They all compliment it and loved it so much! Thanks so much for your recipes :)

Made this tonight - used recipe as written - only variation was to generously sprinkle breadcrumbs on the baking tray as I’d read somewhere that it makes for a crunchy base. And it was pretty crunchy! - so maybe this helped? 
Anyway - tasted superb! Cayenne and nutmeg really gave it punch. 
I especially liked using Greek yoghurt instead of the ricotta that so many other recipes use. Standard Oz supermarket ricotta I don’t think is that great - and it always goes (to my taste) unpleasantly grainy in texture when baked. 
Thanks Nagi! Will certainly be making this again :)

keywords: filo pastry, greek pie, Spanakopita, Spinach pie
